sp.p: Oh admirable! but mee thinks when the doore is open, they ſhould heare it below likewiſe in the Vault, and ſtand ſtill there too.

sp.speaker: Phant.
sp.p: Well, Sir, by my Mothers ſoule (that oath I learn't in Spaine) 'tis a truth; and the reaſon it cannot be heard lower, is, becauſe the ſound does not deſcend below the water.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Indeed, that's an excellent reaſon.

sp.speaker: Phant.
sp.p: Nay, by Ioue, Sir, I ſcorne to lie; I ſcorne to ſpeake any thing without reaſon, by Ioue; by Ioue, Ile giue as good a reaſon of thoſe things I know, as any man vnder the cope of Heauen; I will, by Ioue.

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: Why, I haue ſeene white beares with faces would make you fall in loue with them.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: O ſtrange! white beares! and yet indeed I haue heard that a late in America there are white beares, but they are moſt terrible.

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, and theſe haue long tailes.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: That's ſomewhat worth the admiration; and yet I thinke all Beares at firſt had long tailes, or elſe why ſhould the Beare in the heauens haue one!

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: 'Tis true; yet (if you marke it) 'tis broken.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: O, that came thus; when Iupiter pull'd him vp to heauen by the taile, the waight of his body broke it, whereupon Iupiter caught him by the rumpe, and ſo tyed his taile together againe, & that is the reaſon of the knot in the middle of it, and ſo it has euer ſince hung ſlopeling downe-ward, if you marke it.

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p:
Againe, Sir, in my trauailes in Tuſcany, I beheld a moſt curious piece of Architecture; it was an hall built in the forme of a croſſe, that, which way ſoeuer the wind ſate, or the ſunne ſhin'd, a man might alwayes goe to one of the ends,
and ſo decline the preſent violence of the ſeaſon: and as in an arbour vnto which the Sun has acceſſe, you ſhall ſee boughes at the top correſpondently repreſented on the ground in the ſhaddow: ſo whatſoeuer curious work was ſeene in the roofe of this building, the ſame vnderneath was expreſt in the Floore.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: I fancie the conceit prettily.

sp.speaker: Phant.
sp.p: Nay, Sir; Ile tell you a wonder, wee met with a Trauailour that could ſpeake ſome ſixe languages at the ſame inſtant.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: How? at the ſame inſtant! that's impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Phant.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, the actualitie of the performance puts it beyond all contradiction. With his tongue hee'd vowell you out as ſmooth Italian, as any man breathing: with his Eye he would ſparkle forth the proud Spaniſh: with his Noſe blow out moſt Robuſtious Dutch: the Creaking of his High-heel'd Shoo would articulate exact Polonian: The knocking of his ſhin-bones Foeminine French: and his Belly would grumble moſt pure and Scholer-like Hungary.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: How? his Belly ſpeake?

sp.speaker: Phant.
sp.p: Alas, that's the leaſt wonder, for at what time Pythagoras flouriſh'd, that was a familiar thing with his Scholers: and I may confirme it by a perſwaſiue induction drawne from your Pythoniſſes, and your new-faſhion'd Lutes that ſound from within, Sir, from within: nay, beſides all this, Sir, at the ſame time his Eares could ſing, and his Braines crow; and he could Laugh till the teares ſtood in's Eyes.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: O wonderfull! wonderfull!

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: If you pleaſe, Sir, now to imploy mee, not onely my Wants, but alſo my Loue ſhall make mee diligently reſpectfull.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Sir, I courteouſly accept your offered indeuours.

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: Ah, deareſt Aſtronomia, 'tis for thy ſake I doe thus. He ſpeakes this aſide to himſelfe, and Poeta ouer-heares him.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: How? for Aſtronomia's? [hee ſpake that to himſelfe] Sir, I am on a ſuddaine leſſe well affected, wherefore pardon, I pray you, an abrupt intreating of your preſent departure, and ſome ſpeedie occaſion ſhall ſhortly offer a ſecond meeting.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: Well Sir, we thanke you; Apollo be alwayes the Patrone of your Muſe and Health.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: For Aſtronomia's ſake? why? is he in loue with her? (For Aſtronomia's ſake!) or is hee in loue with mee! I woun't torture my ſelfe, Ile expound gently; Hee's in loue with mee, and becauſe (it may be) he heares I loue her, hee accounts (it may bee) that hee does this, that I may obtaine her: and thus (it may be) hee meanes hee does this for Her: This is Scuruie; Maſter Geographus you haue marr'd your owne Market; my ſtomacke's turn'd; I haue Tongues enow for a wiſe-man; thouſands before me haue got Wife and Children, more then thy could keepe, without learning the Languages; and therefore from hence-forth, for feare of the worſt, you may, Maſter Geographus, (if you pleaſe) vndertake a ſecond Trauell.

item.label: POETA
item.hi: in his Night-cap and Slippers, vnbutton'd and vntruſt.

sp.speaker: POETA.
sp.l: Melancholico comes in, and layes down 〈…〉 & departs. BE not farre off.
That nothing is entire!
Nothing all-bleſt! but ſtill ſome new deſire
Brings a new torture! and this Fate does lie,
An heauie weight on all mortalitie!
It does; thus was not lately my affection
Chain'd to Hiſtoria by a ſtrong ſubiection?
Did I not pule, and pine, intreate, and crie?
Pretend a ſickneſſe? threaten I would die,
If ſhe not lou'd me? did I not act all
The frantike parts wherewith Loue does inthrall
His Rebell-Subiects? Did I not looke Sad
If ſhee but Frown'd; and, if ſhee Smil'd, looke Glad?
I did; and tooke delight to be inchain'd
To her, Hope ſaid at laſt ſhee might be gain'd.
Yet ſee the wheele of change! I now doe ſcorne
Her teares, and now ſhe thinkes her ſelfe forlorne.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Pardon my intruſion Sir, Hiſtoria Melancholico enters.
Hearing you were hurt lately in a Fray,
Has in her iealouſie of loue ſent here
Some Phyſicke, to preuent a greater feare.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.l: She ſhould haue ſent me Poyſon, far from her
I count it ſo; yet let the Meſſenger
Returne our courteous gratitude. Begon. Exit Melancholico.
Lo, thus vexations neuer come alone;
Well, I woun • t loue her; nay, Ile ha •• her more
Hence-forth; ſhe plagues me worſe then before.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Pardon once more, Sir, here comes ſent by her,
Medicus, Seruant to adminiſter
The Phyſicke.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.l: —Why, I prethee know I lacke
No Phyſicke, there 'tis, thou maiſt carry't backe.

sp.speaker: Sanguis.
sp.p: The Gods forbid, Sir, this is Poyſon. Sanguis lookes on the poyſon.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: — How!

sp.speaker: Sanguis.
sp.p: 'Tis Poyſon, Sir.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.l: —Why? it was ſent but now
From my Loue-ſicke Historia.

sp.speaker: Sanguis.
sp.l: —So 't may be:
They'ue chang'd my Maſters Phyſicke.

lg.l: —Oh to ſee
The Treacherie of women! well, conceale
The fact as yet; iuſt time ſhall all reueale.
O Women, Witches, Monſters, Furies Deuils,
The impure extract of a World of euils;
Natures great Errour; the obliquitie
Of the Gods Wiſdome; and th' Anomalie
From all that's good; I'l curſe you all below
The Center, and, if I could, then further throw
Your curſed heads; and if any ſhould gaine
A place in Heau'n, Ile time 'em downe againe
To a worſe ruine; yet me thinkes I heare
How Aſtronomia whiſpers in mine eare,
And begs a Pardon for them; well; to thee
I'l yeeld, thou ſtand'ſt aboue mortalitie.
Aſpire, my gentle Muſe, inflame my breſt;
Then thus my gracefull loue ſhall be expreſt.
Her Brow is like a braue Heroicke line,
That does a ſacred Maieſtie inſhrine.
Her Noſe Phaleuciake-like in comely ſort
Ends in a Trochie, or a long and ſhort.
Her Mouth is like a prettie Dimeter;
Her Eie-browes like a little-longer Trimeter.
Her Chinne is an Adonicke; and her Tongue—
Is an Hyp • rmeter, ſomewhat too-long.
Her Eies, I may compare them vnto two
Quick-turning Dactyles, for their nimble View.
Her Necke A • clepiad-like turnes round about
Behind, before a little bone ſtands out.
Her Ribs like Staues of Sapphickes doe deſcend
Thither, which but to name were to offend.
Her Armes like two Iambickes rais'd on hie,
Doe with her Brow beare equall Maieſtie.
Her Legs like two ſtrait Spondies, keep a pace
Slow as two Scazons, but with ſtately grace.
Thankes to my Muſe; yet why doe I admire
Her thus, whom I enioy but by deſire?
For more I neuer ſhall; this is my waight
Of griefe, and this my preordained Fate.
He takes vp his Lute. Come, come, thou part of Heau'n, companion
Of all my woes and loues, thou that alone
Doſt in the mid'ſt of ſorrowes yeeld reliefe,
And though not take away, make leſſe my griefe.
lg.stage: He playes on his Lute, then leaues off, and ſpeakes againe.
lg.l: My deareſt Lute, Apoollo's beſt inuention
Wherewith he does compoſe the wilde diſſention
Of our vntun'd deſires, which would confound
Vs quite, but that they breake forth with a ſound!
Sighes frō our breſts are like ſounds frō thy wombe,
Borne dead, and buri'd in an aërie Tombe.
Sigh then to Cupid, tell him he's too blame
Not raiſing in my loue a mutuall flame.

stage.hi: He playes on his Lute, and leauing off, cals to his man

sp.speaker: MELANCHOLICO.
sp.p: Ho, Melancholico.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: —Here Sir.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: —Begon.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Did you not call me Sir?

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: —Sirrah, begon.
sp.stage: He playes a little on his Lute, and then cals MELANCHOLICO againe.
sp.p: Ho, Melancholico.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: —Sir.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: Dance, I ſay, Dance.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: —I can't.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.l: —Sirrah, dance that which I play.
sp.stage: He playes the Antique on his Lute, and MELANCHOLICO dances, then abruptly leauing off, he ſpeakes to him.
sp.l: Begon: MELANCHOLICO continues dancing. Sirrah, begon.
sp.stage: Hee playes againe on his Lute, and ſuddenly leauing off, throwes it away.
sp.l: —Away, away,
Charmer, Inchanter, tis a truth to ſay,
Our bodies caſt their ſhapes into the Ayre,
And can appeare when they are gon; ſo rare
Philoſophers haue held, and ſo I hold:
Pardon, great Aſtronomia, I was bold,
Too-bold, I doe confeſſe, but my dimme ſight
Could not before behold thee though ſo bright.
But now mine eyes are cleer'd; on my bow'd knee,
I aske a Pardon of thy Maieſtie.
Pardon thy Poet, and vouchſafe this grace, He faines Aſtronomia to be preſent, fals on his knees, imbraces and kiſſes the ayre: then riſes.
That thy rich beauties he may thus imbrace.
And now, deare Loue, adde hereunto one kiſſe,
And then thou ſhalt in heau'n my ſoule with bliſſe.
Maro, thy Riddle's ſolu'd: I thus vntye
The knot, which thou didſt knit, mens wits to try.
Dic quibus in terris (& eris mihi magnus APOLLO)

l.hi: Tres pateat Coeli ſpatium (non amplius) vlnas?

sp.l: Maro, 'tis here; here's Aſtronomia;
Here's Heau'n clos'd in thoſe narrow limits; nay,
Here's Deitie, the obiect of all loues,
Enough to make a thouſand Heau'ns of Ioues.
See, He thinkes he ſees her aſcending into Heauen. ſee, how ſhe aſcends! mount, mount, great Queene
Of Heau'n, and in full luſtre be thou ſeene
Mortalities amazement; ſee, ſhe's gone
To mount yet higher to a ſtately Throne,
Plac'd on the Azure pauement of the Starres,
Guarded by Dayes, Monthes, Houres, then ſees the warres
Of Pygmie-mortals—. Enter MELANCHOLICO.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: —Sir, here's Ethicus
Is come, and ſayes hee'd ſpeake with you.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.l: —With vs?
Admit him in. Exit Melancholico. Enter ETHICVS.

sp.speaker: Ethicus.
sp.l: —Hay! ſcarce dreſt yet! how ſo?

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.l: What? comes your froward age to chide vs?

sp.speaker: Ethicus.
sp.l: —No.
But to inuite you to a Feaſt, my ſelfe your friend,
Deſirous of your peace, to ſet an end
To your contentions with Grammaticus
And Logicus, to night doe purpoſe thus
To make you friends.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.l: But—

sp.speaker: Ethicus.
sp.l: —Nay, no buts: Be there.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Ethicus.
sp.l: —Why thankes. Welcome ſhall be your cheere.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.l: Well then, Ile in and dreſſe me, and ſo come,
Yet better 〈◊〉 purchance you had my roome. Exit Poeta.

sp.p:
〈…〉
•… o deale with ſpirits?

〈…〉
•… ly a Grometrician, it is lawfull
for you to deale only with bodies: but if you will vndertake Our Superiour facultie, 'tis not onely lawfull, but moſt honourable; why Sir, 'tis one of the greateſt gifts of the Gods to haue command ouer Spirits; but for the approbation of it, you may only looke backe vnto the antiquitie thereof, which is drawne from more then eight hundred yeeres before the Siege of Troy, in the time of Agonaces, and of the renowned Zoroaſter a King of the Bactrians, who deſcribed the high Myſterie of this Diuine Science in an hundred thouſand verſes; after theſe there flouriſhed Iobeth, Toluſcol, Zamolxis, whoſe admired fame was afterwards emulated by Almadal, Alchindus, and Hipocus Arabians: Apuſcorus, Zaratus, and Cobares, Medians: Marmaridius, a Babylonian: Zarmocenidas, an Aſſyrian, Abbaris, an Hyperborean, Theſphetion, an Aethiopian, Arnuphis, an Aegyptian, Theurgus, a Chaldean: with theſe I may recite Cambyſes, Zamares, Charondas, Dam • gorgon, Gobrias, Arbatel, Apollonius, Gog, Hoſtanes, Atyr, Choaſtes—

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: Good Sir, doe not coniure.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: No Sir, theſe are nothing but the names of the Sacred Profeſſours of this Diuine Science.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: I but it may be Sir, they had coniuring names.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p:
Alas, Sir! 'tis not ſo eaſie a matter to worke effectually in our Sacred Science, as moſt men thinke it is, and as I will moſt manifeſtly declare vnto you; for this is a rule, you muſt be firſt an Abſolute Aſtrologian; vpon which fundamentall Suppoſition I thus proceed: before you can obtaine the knowledge of Aſtrologie, you muſt be a moſt Grounded Philoſopher, a ſound Phyſician, and an exquiſite Mathematician; by the helpes of which Sciences you ſhall know the courſes of the Starres; the number of the Orbes; your Poles; the Circles; the Verticall and Pedall points; the Azimuth, or Verticall Circle; the Almucantarath or Circles of Altitude; the Concentricitie and Excentricitie of the Orbes; the Aſcendent, and Deſcendent Knots, or Syndeſmes, that Cut the Ecliptike; your Orbes Aequant, Epicyclicall, and Deferent of the Apogeum, and Perigeum, or of the Higheſt and Loweſt Abſis; the Planetarie Aſpects, or Configurations, either Right
as Coniunction and Oppoſition, or Collaterall as Sextile, Quadrate, and Trine; the Direct motion of the Planets, their Retrogradation & Station; then Sir, your Aſtrologie is either Canonicall for the Influence of the Starres, or Thematicall for the Erection of a Scheme of the Heauens, wherein is to bee knowne the Order of the Domicils, and the Inſcription. Then there is your Iudiciarie, which is either Genethliacall, or Catholike inſtructing in predictions, either Idiomaticall or Symptomaticall; the eight and twentie Manſions of the Moone; the Symbolization of Occult qualities in Herbs, with the Planets; Signacles, Pentacles, Planetarie Suffumigations, Vnctions, Pailters, Rings, Alligations, Suſpenſions; the twelue Scales of the Numbers; the Duodenarie Scale, either Cabaliſticall or Orphicall; the Characters, Seales, and Bands of Spirits—

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: You'l giue me all this in writing Sir; woun't you?

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Yes Sir, yes. Then are there diuers kinds of your Magicke, as Necromancie, Anthropomancie, Gaſtromancie, Cheiromancie, Coſcinomancy,—

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: I pray, doe you your ſelfe know how many there are in all?

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Sir, One and twentie. Ile begin them ouer againe, if you will. Necromancie, Anthropomancie—

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: Nay, good Sir hold, we haue enough alreadie: But I perceiue you Magicians haue admirable memories to get hard words by heart; I maruaile you doe not turne Dictionarie-makers: Why? I warrant there's no hard word but you can tell the meaning on't: you'd put all their noſes out of ioynt quite.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p:
I, and put them out of their wits, if wee liſt: But then, Sir, to know the Spirit of Euerie Day, and Houre; his Name, Power, and Legions vnder him, his Forme of appearing, whether like a Dragon, or an Horſe, or a Wolfe, or a flame of fire; the Region whence he comes; the Gift hee beſtowes, whether Learning, Riches, Beautie; his Name, his Characters: theſe, theſe, are the wonders, the amazements of our Spirituall Science; Spirituall I may iuſtly call in, ſince euerie Art receiues an Excellencie from its Obiect; and yet (alas!)
I confeſſe, I am but young in it yet, and haue ſcarce ſerued a 'prentice-ſhip in it, if it may bee call'd a ſeruitude, wherein there is ſuch Freeneſſe, and Euagation of ſpirit in ſuch exquiſite knowledge; nay, Dominion ouer Spirits.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: Young ſay you? marry, I thinke, you are abſolutely grounded in it, that can know all theſe Myſteries; ah, were it the will of the gods, I had but halfe of this skill, I'de giue all that I haue, and get more as I could; but can you doe all theſe Wonders?

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Farre ſtranger, farre ſtranger; moſt amazing tranſformations; why, there was Apuleius ſo skilfull in this Arte, that he turn'd himſelfe into an Aſſe, and Lucian was turn'd into an Aſſe, before he ſtudi'd it.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: O ſtrange! but can a Spirit giue Learning?

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Oh, there was Hermolaus Barbarus, when he ſtudied Philoſophie, and leſſe vnderſtood any place, hee would call vp a Spirit to inſtruct him; ſo the famous Cardans father carryed one alwaies in a Ring on his finger; and Agrippa had his Dogge with a Characteriz'd Collar.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: But can you by your Art, tell mee whether or no I ſhall haue Aſtronomia?

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Any thing.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Why, I can doe it by Coſcinomancie.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: By the turning of a Siue.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: But I haue heard, that's onely for things ſtolne.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Ah, 'tis more generall, and that you ſhall ſee; ſtay here, Ile but ſtep forth. Exit Magus.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: Well, this is the man whom the Heauens haue ordain'd to make me happie; O Ʋenus, be fauourable vnto me, and Ile build thee a fayrer Temple then euer the Epheſians directed to Diana. MAGVS enters.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p:
Come Sir, here are Sheeres and a Siue; I muſt faſten the Sheeres? now doe as I bid you; Hold vp the ſide of the Sheeres with your finger. (he puts the wrong finger) Nay, come, your middle-finger: So; now muſt I ſay a myſticall forme of powerfull words, and then name thoſe that wee ſuſpect
ſhall haue her; and amongſt them name you alſo; and at whoſe name the Siue turnes, he ſhall haue her.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: If it do's not turne at mine, I ſhall die: 'pray make it turne at mine.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Nay, then it muſt goe for nothing, for it muſt turne of its owne accord. Be ſilent now. Dies mies, Ieſchet, bene doefet, Dowim • , Enitemaus. Who ſhall haue Aſtronomia? Shall Poeta? (It ſtands ſtill.) Who ſhall haue Aſtronomia? Shall Logicus?

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: Hee's not in loue with her, Sir; 'pray doe not you put in him too.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: O vile! peace; now muſt I begin againe. Diet mies, Ieſchet, Bene doefet, Dowima, Enitemaus. Who ſhall haue Aſtronomia? Shall Poeta? (It ſtands ſtill.) Who ſhall haue Aſtronomia? Shall Logicus? (It ſtands ſtill.) Who ſhall haue Aſtronomia? Shall Geographus? (It moues a little.) Who ſhall haue Aſtronomia? Shall Geometres? (It turnes round.) Shall he obtaine her by Coniuration? (It ſtands ſtill.) Shall hee obtaine her by Medicine? (It moues a little.) Shall hee obtaine her by Faſcination? (It turnes round.)

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: Georaetres falls downe on his knees, and imbraces Magus his knees. Magus, what's mine is yours, goods, life, ſoule, and all: Ʋenus, thy temple ſhall be a mile in length; thy Image in't ſhall be greater then the Coloſſus at Rhodes, it ſhall bee all white Marble: The temple at Millaine ſhall looke like pale-fac'd •• llow to it; it ſhall haue as many pillars, as there are houres in the yeere, and as many windowes as there are minutes; and the Spire ſhall be higher then Tenariffa, or the Tower of Babylon by eight ſcore Meaſured ſurlongs at the leaſt. Magus, I haue enough, I haue enough.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Nay but, Sir, you muſt Meaſure your ioy; diuers haue died with ouer-much reioycing, and ſo may you; and then you'd both breake your vow to the Goddeſſe, and loſe your Loue beſides.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: You ſay true.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Beſides, you muſt vſe a meanes you ſee, Faſcination; which you ſhall vſe at the Banquet, which (you know) we are inuited vnto.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p:
Nay, let mee alone for looking on her; Ile looke
thorow her, and thorow her; and make her as Perſpectiue, as I am Solid.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Beſides, there was a little moouing, you ſaw, at the name of Geographus: to ſignifie hee will bee faire for her too. And againe, there was a little moouing at the word Medicine, and therefore that muſt bee vs'd too: but for that take you no care.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: Well, you learned men put ſo many doubts—but I care not, I ſhall haue her in the end: come, I'ue enough, now let's goe.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Meaſure your ioy, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: Thou'rt mine, thou'rt mine, Aſtronomia, I'me in Heau'n already; Geographus may goe trauaile againe, and Poeta, in ſtead of Baies, may goe weare a Willow-garland.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Come, let's in. Exeunt Geometres & Magus.
MArry, and I bee thus troubled with you when you woo me, and ſeeke to pleaſe; what ſhould I expect and wee were married once?

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Nay, deareſt Logicus, let not the excellencie of your reaſon bee ſo ſeuere, but that it may admit a gracious apprehenſion of a ſmiling loue; let not the exactnes of your wiſedome be ſo regulated, but that it may expreſſe a courteous acceptance of a Louers admiration; let not—

sp.speaker: Log.
sp.p: Nay, and you once fall to Set ſpeeches, I am gone; I perceiue you are not for common talke; I wonder, now I thinke on't, in what Praedicament a womans tongue is; let's ſee: yet, what if I make it a Tranſcendent? and yet it can't be ſo, for 'tis neither vnum, nor verum, nor honum: 'faith, and't bee in any Praedicament, it ſhall bee in Quantitate Continua, and that's oppoſite to Diſcreta; or rather, ſince 'tis ſo irregular, and therefore can hardly bee admitted into any Order, I will count it that Monſter in Nature, and Contradiction of Philoſophie, Infinitum in acta.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p:
Why lo, now your ſelfe has made a ſet ſpeech; and
thus whilſt you Reprehend, you Offend: whilſt you Direct, you Neglect: whilſt you Reforme, you Deforme: whilſt you—

sp.speaker: Log.
sp.p: Hey day! this is tick-tack: Here's another ſhorter tricke: well, I perceiue there's no other courſe — which is your way?

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Which is your way?

sp.speaker: Log.
sp.p: Doe you ſpeake firſt.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Nay, doe you ſpeake firſt, you are the better Man.

sp.speaker: Log.
sp.p: VVhy, mine lies this way.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: VVhy ſo does mine; weele goe together.

sp.speaker: Log.
sp.p: I, But I muſt go this way to doe a little buſineſſe firſt.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: VVhy ſo muſt I.

sp.speaker: Log.
sp.p: But I muſt walke here alone a little to thinke on't firſt.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: VVhy, and I muſt walke here alone a little firſt.

sp.speaker: Log.
sp.p: Why, then fare you well; I can thinke on my buſines by the way.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Why, and I can very well thinke on my buſineſſe by the way.

sp.speaker: Log.
sp.p: Why, you woun't follow me? I am going to a Feaſt.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Why, and I am going to a Feaſt.

sp.speaker: Log.
sp.p: I am going to Ethicus.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Why, and I am going to Ethicus.

sp.speaker: Log.
sp.p: O you gods! which of you will come to deliuer me? Well, if wee muſt together, and if you will ſticke ſo cloſe vnto me; yet, good Miſtres Tongue, do not cleaue to the roofe of my Mouth.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: No, no; your lippe is all that I deſire.

div.head: ACTVS III. SCENA IIII.
div.stage: MVSICA at one doore: GEOGRAPHVS and PHANTASTES at another.

sp.p: TAra, ding de ding, ding de ding, lan, tan, dan, dido.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: How now my nimble Crotchet? who was the firſt Fiddle-maker?

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: Thats's a queſtion, Sir.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: Why, for that reaſon I propos'd it.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: Why, for that reaſon you might haue propos'd many more.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: I, but Anſwere.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: I, but I muſt know firſt; 'tis a great controuerſie.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: What then was the firſt kinde of Inſtrument?

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: Why, that's as hard.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: Why, I can tell.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: An Harpe.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: I but you're deceiu'd, I rather thinke 'twas a Bagge-pipe.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: A Bag-pipe? why prethee?

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: Why? marry, firſt vnderſtand this reaſon, and then Ile ſhew you: You know euery Art both drawes it's imitation from Nature, and labours to perfect it, which it does by finding comforts to preſerue it: Muſicke then at the firſt was found out as an antidote againſt griefe: and by this meanes, when men were grieued, they cried Oh, and there was one Note: then Hey-ho, there were two Notes more. So, when they laught, they obſeru'd three more by Ha, ha, ho. Theſe being firſt ioyn'd together, and afterwards variouſly intermixt, were the firſt harmonie in voice; which being repeated vnto grieued mindes, were as it were a prettie deluding of their ſorrowes; and theſe by obſeruation were afterwards reduc'd to inſtrument—

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: I conceit it, Muſica.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: Thus, men perceiuing that theſe notes were conceiu'd in the bellie, and afterwards, (as it were) form'd in the paſſage of the throat, ſowed Leather in the forme of a Bellie, or bagge; and wth a Reed made a long Necke vnto it, and a Winde-pipe; which when they blew full of winde, and perceiu'd it gaue no ſound, they cut many holes in the reed to let it out, and then alternately ſtopping the holes, they found an admirable varietie of harmony; and as the holes ſerue for diſtinction of notes in a Winde-inſtrument, ſo doe your frets on a String'd-inſtrument.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p:
Indeede I thinke this a truth; for as the voice was before the Inſtrument, ſo the Winde-inſtrument before the
ſtring'd. But then how came your Trumpet vp?

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: Why, on this manner: When Triton came to helpe the gods in the Warres of the Gyants, he wanted a weapon, and finding the ſhell of a Fiſh, he did blow in't, which yeelded a moſt hideous noiſe: the Gyants thinking it had beene ſome terrible beaſt, fled away affrighted, and ſince by a perfecting imitation, men haue alter'd both the matter, and the forme of that Inſtrument.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: Nay, I do beleeue there is a great vertue in Muſicke.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: O Sir, 'tis your onely medicine of the minde.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: Indeed I thinke ſo, and that's the reaſon, 'tis likely, why Apollo is the god both of Muſicke and Phyſicke: and now I remember it, in one place where we came, in our trauailes, there were no Phyſicions, but all their ſicke folks were cur'd by Muſicke; where was it, Phantaſtes? I haue quite forgot.

sp.speaker: Phant.
sp.p: Why 'twas in Creet Sir, where Iupiter was nurs'd, and the Muſicke was made with thoſe Kettle-drums, which they ſounded to drowne the crying of Iupiter, when he was in his ſwathe-bands: in reward of which loue, hee procur'd of Apollo, in the fauour of the Cretians, that at the ſound of thoſe Kettle-drummes all ſicke folkes, whoſe time of death was not come, ſhould without any languiſhing ſicknes immediately recouer; and therefore the order is, when any one is ſicke, they carry him preſently in a Litter to the Temple where theſe Drums are kept; and if hee does not ſtraight-wayes recouer, they carry him home againe, as a man that muſt dye, and ſo prouide for his funerall.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: Where is this Sir? in Creet?

sp.speaker: Phant.
sp.p: Yes, in Creet.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: I, but I haue heard, the Cretians are mightie liars.

sp.speaker: Phant.
sp.p: Vpon the Faith of a Trauellour, the Honeſtie of a Courtier, and the Word of a Gentleman, 'tis a moſt confirm'd truth.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: Indeed theſe three are much about one valew.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: VVell, Muſica, I could talke with thee all day—

sp.speaker: Phant.
sp.p: I, and all night too.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p:
But I cannot ſtay now; I'me afraid they ſtay for me
at the banquet. Is thy Miſtris there?

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: Yes, I thinke, by this time.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: Well, farewell till anon: you'll meet vs at ſupper? woun't you?

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: Yes, yes; I'me going for Muſike. Exit Geogra.

sp.speaker: Phant.
sp.p: Come, my prettie Pigeon, let's bill a little; is't poſſible, Phantaſtes and Muſica ſhould meet, and part without a kiſſe?—now farewell. Exit Phantaſtes.

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: Ah: theſe Courtiers are lycouriſh-lip'd: but I muſt goe fetch the Muſike, To ra ding de ding, ding de ding, lan, tan dan dido. Exit Muſica.

div.head: ACTVS III. SCENA V.
ETHICVS, GEOMETRES, LOGICVS, POETA, GRAMMATICVS, MAGVS, ASTRONOMIA, ARITHMETICA, RHETORICA, ASTROLOGIA, CHOLER.

sp.p: WElcome, welcome, all of you; i'good faith, I'm e'en young againe, to ſee ſuch a jolly company of my friends together: but, paſſion o' me! why, Oeconoma?

sp.speaker: Oecon.
sp.p: I, I, preſently, preſently, Shee ſpeakes from within. wee'r making all haſte wee can.

sp.speaker: Ethic.
sp.p:
Ah, there's a good huſwife, neither meat oth' table, nor cloth laid, nor any thing in a readineſſe. Good friends pardon vs, wee are ſomewhat vnmannerly to make you ſtay thus; wee'll talke till ſupper is ſeru'd in; but where's Geographus?
Enter GEOGRAPHVS and PHANTASTES. Oh here is; welcome, welcome.

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: Thanks, They all ſalute him, & he them mutually, eſpecially the Ladies. courteous Ethicus—ſaue you gallants— faire Ladies—

sp.speaker: Ethic.
sp.p: Phantaſtes, and Choler, [Enter MVSICA] and thou Muſica, now thou art come, be a little forward to make a ſupply for our backwardneſſe, and ſtep in to my wife to help out ſupper quickly: (Exeunt Phantaſt. Choler, & Muſica) why 'tis well, 'tis well, now 'tis as it ſhould be, all friends, all friends: but where's Hiſtoria?

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Hiſtoria? why, aske Poeta.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Mee?

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: I, you; they ſay ſhee's ſicke of loue.

sp.speaker: Ethic.
sp.p: Poeta, where's your man Melancholico?

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Faith, when I was comming hither, hee was in a dump, and therefore I thinking him not fit to come to a banquet, left him behind me; and indeed that's his fault, hee will not commonly be merry in company.

sp.speaker: Ethic.
sp.p: Logicus, where's your man Phlegmatico?

sp.speaker: Logic.
sp.p: Faith, as I was comming, my Slauerer was at his Tobacco, but, I thinke, I made him ſmoke for his labour, and ſo would not let him come, for hee would nothing but haue ſpawl'd in your roome, Phantaſtes, Choler, Muſica, bring in Supper. and haue turn'd your ſtomakes.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Well, remember this Phantaſtes.

sp.speaker: Phant.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: That you carry in the march-pane and not I, but Ile—

sp.speaker: Phant.
sp.p: What? amn't I the better man?

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Would ſupper were done: I'd bumme you.

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Phant.
sp.p: Why, Sir, he's angrie that I brought in the marchpane.

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: Phantaſtes, Choler, Muſica, go out againe Come, be mannerly.

sp.speaker: Gram.
sp.p: Why, ſirrah, Choler, will you ſtill be quarrelling?

sp.speaker: Ethic.
sp.p: You ſhould let him be my man a little; faith I ſhould be as froward as he; we two ſhould haue a bickering once a day. (Choler to Phantaſt. as they come in with more ſeruice.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: I would ſupper were done once for your ſake.

sp.speaker: Gram.
sp.p: Why, ſirrah, are you ſtill grumbling?

sp.speaker: Oecon.
sp.p: Come, friends, you are all welcome, we haue made you ſtay here too-long for a little ſorry cheere; come husband will you place the gueſts?

sp.speaker: Ethic.
sp.p: Sit downe, you know your places; ſit downe (they all ſit downe) wife, bid them welcome.

sp.speaker: Oecon.
sp.p: You are all heartily welcome, heartily welcome.

sp.speaker: Ethic.
sp.p: Why, Muſica, where are the Muſicians?

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: Here, Sir, here.

sp.speaker: Ethic.
sp.p:
Come on, play, feed you our eares, whilſt we ſeed our bellyes. The muſike playes; Geographus drinks to Aſtronomia; ſhee to Geome
•••• ; hee to Arithmetica ſhee to Aſtrologia; ſhee drinks to Aſtronomia, then •• ally caſts in a powder: which being done, Phantaſtes ſings.

l.hi: If you fell not at ods,
And did not your ſelues annoy.
But when pride does once tickle,
And bring vs in tune againe.
And turne with each ſtrong wind.
Where Muſicke and Loue do meet!
To make his pipe ſound more ſweet:
Where the Wine in the boules,
And trippe it in comely ſort.

sp.speaker: Ethic.
sp.p: Here, Logicus, you ſhall drinke to Poeta,

sp.speaker: Logic.
sp.p: I accept your Propoſition, Sir; Poeta, to ſet a Concluſion to our former diſſentions, and to make a plaine Demonſtration of reconcilement, I drinke to you. He drinkes.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: With the moſt ingenuous freedome of a Poet, I accept it: Grammaticus, that our contention ending in loue, may make a Tragike-Comedie, I drinke to you. He drinkes.

sp.speaker: Gram.
sp.p: I proteſt to you, Sir, I doe put all former wrongs in the praeter-plu-perfect Tence, and am glad of this happy Coniunction, and that we are all of vs in ſuch a merry Mood: but by the way, my Maſters, theſe Noune-Adiectiues of the Foeminine gender, ſit all this while vn-drunke to: Aſtronomia. He offers to drinke to Aſtronomia. —

sp.speaker: Aſtron.
sp.p: Intruth, Grammaticus, I am not in Caſe to pledge you: I pledg'd Aſtrologia euen now, and I am not ſince halfe well.

sp.speaker: Gram.
sp.p: Arithmetica—

sp.speaker: Arith.
sp.p: If you Count again, you ſhal find that I drunk laſt.
Rhetorica—here's to moyſten your eloquent tongue.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: An eloquent tongue is neuer drie, Aſtrologia will pledge you for me.

sp.speaker: Gram.
sp.p: Aſtrologia—

sp.speaker: Aſtrol.
sp.p: In troth I haue been drinking my Belly full of Nectar; but iuſt now, my thoughts were vpon the preſent Coniunction of Mars and Ʋenus.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Why how now, Grammaticus! who doe you drinke to? faith thou art now a Noune Subſtantiue indeed, for thou ſtandſt alone by thy ſelfe, without being ioyn'd to any of theſe Adiectiues.

sp.speaker: Gram.
sp.p: Nay, doe not you ieſt.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: What? doſt thou make a Ieſter of me?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Nay, I Coniure you both; by our preſent meeting, that you goe not out of the Circle of harmeleſſe mirth.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Me thinks I ſee a Direct line paſſe from the Eye of Geometres to Aſtronomia's.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Nay, will you, Poeta? you make Aſtronomia bluſh.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Some Aqua vitae, I ſay, for Geometres.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Why, Poeta?

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Why, hee's a dying I thinke, his eyes are fixt in's head alreadie.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: It may be, Poeta, you meaſure Geometres his lookes by your owne.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Me thinks I ſee a Direct line paſſe from the Eye of Geometres to Aſtronomia's.

sp.speaker: Aſtron.
sp.p: I'm eu'n ſtifled, I doe not vſe to be in ſuch a cloſe Roome, I loue the Open Aire.

sp.speaker: Oecon.
sp.p: Alas! Aſtronomia's extreme ill. Exeunt Aſtronomia & Oeconoma.

sp.speaker: Ethic.
sp.p: Friends, you are all heartily welcome, reſt you here I pray, and weele in with her. Exit Ethicus.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Aſtrologia, follow her, and ſee you be neuer from her all the while ſhee's ſicke.

sp.speaker: Aſtrol.
sp.p: I ſaw this diſaſtrous chance in the ſtarres, for as Mars and Venus were ſporting, they were beheld by the reſt of the enuious gods. Exit.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p:
Ile in too, to ſit and Talke with her, whiles ſhee's
ſicke. Exit Rhetorica.

sp.speaker: Arith.
sp.p: Ile in too, that I may —

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: Be made ſit downe againe.

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: Alas, my Miſtris!

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: Shee did not looke well.

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: Aſtronomia ſicke? then all the Heauen's awry, and my Muſike's quite out of tune. Exit Muſica.

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: 'Twas, I feare me, a fit of an Ague.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Aſtronomia in a fit of an Ague? I neuer vnderſtood the Motus trepidationis of the Heauen before.

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: Muſicians, depart the roome. The Muſicians go out.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: By Ioue I came to be merry, and I will be merry. Here's an health to Aſtronomia. He drinks.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: Here's a health to Aſtronomia. He drinks.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: Here's a health to Aſtronomia. He drinks.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Sir, you wrong vs all, not to take off your full meaſure.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, they that drinke with Meaſure, drinke without Meaſure.

sp.speaker: Arith.
sp.p: I, indeed, for they that Number their cups, commonly Multiply their cups.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: He loues not Aſtronomia, that does not pledge her a whole one.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: Well, becauſe 'tis to her, Ile doo't, He drinks.

sp.speaker: Logic.
sp.p: I can't drinke.

sp.speaker: Gram.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Arith.
sp.p: You woun't, I know, require it of me.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Well, and you woun't, here's to you that will: A ſecond health to Aſtronomia. He drinks.

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: A ſecond health to Aſtronomia. He drinks.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: A ſecond health to Aſtronomia. He drinks.

sp.speaker: Phant.
sp.p: By Ioue I muſt be merry, and I will be merry; can you ſing?

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: Beginne, wee'll follow.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: Beginne, wee'll follow.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Haue at you then.

l.hi: FIll up my boule to the brim-a,
That my lips in wine may ſwim-a;
And the world may it know:
Fill vp my boule to the brimme-a
And the world may it know:
Fill vp my bowle to the brimme-a.
O my Iacobs ſtaffe is broken,
O my Iacobs ſtaffe is broken.
Come kiſſe, come kiſſe, my Corinna,
And ſtill that ſport wee'l beginn-a,
That our ſoules ſo may meet
In our lippes, while they greet:
Come kiſſe, come kiſſe, my Corinna.
That our ſoules ſo may meet
In our lippes, while they greet:
Come kiſſe, come kiſſe, my Corinna.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: Here's a health to Aſtronomia.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: Here's a health to Aſtronomia.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: Here's a health to Aſtronomia. Prethee Poeta doe thou ſing a Catch alone, and wee'l ſing the Cloſe with thee.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: A match, hay boyes.

l.hi: As it is toſt on by-a
Till at laſt they fall to blowes,
Till at laſt the fall to blowes,
Let the world ſay what it will
And drinke your drinke all out-a.
Let the world ſay what it will
And drinke your drinke all out-a.
As thou doſt freely quaffe a.
Be as merry as a King
And Sound a luſty laugh a.
Be as merry as a King
And ſound a luſty laugh a.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Here's a health to Aſtronomia. He drinks.

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: Faith, I can drinke no more, Poeta.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: How? not pledge me? Choler, fil the bowle againe; by Ioue, not pledge me? pledge me, pledge me, Geographus: for by Ioue—

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: I will drinke with thee, and I will ſing with thee, and I will fight with thee.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Nay, 'pray let's haue no fighting.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: By Ioue. I will drinke with thee, I will ſing with thee, and I will fight with thee.

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: By Ioue you're almoſt foxt.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: By Ioue (He drinks) you lowſie-ſhirted rogue, you ſit aboue mee? did not you begge entertaynment of me tother day?

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: Sleepe, ſleepe, Poeta. Exit Geographus.

sp.speaker: Phant.
sp.p: A rope of a drunken foole; I'ue loſt my ſupper by this: I muſt follow my Maſter. Exit Phant.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Ten-toes, I know you're a good footman; Come, Geometres, I hope you'll ſit ſquarely to it ſtill.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: Nay, if I cannot Rule others, I will Rule my ſelfe. Exit Geometres.

sp.speaker: Arith.
sp.p: And if Geometres depart, Arithmetica will be none of the Number. Exit Arith.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Farewell, Hoſteſſe; we ſhall be ſure to haue no reckoning now Arithmetica's gone: and yet Ile pay you ſomewhat, Clinch-fiſt. (Hee beates Logicus, and ouer-turnes the Table; then fals on Grammaticus, and Choler.) Hay tables! Hay!

sp.speaker: Logic.
sp.p:
Well, you drunken rogue, Ile haue an Oppoſition
for you before Polites, that you ſhall not be able to Anſwere to. Exit Logicus.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Farewell block-head: now pae-da-gog, pa-da-gog: I muſt ſay my Part to you too.

sp.speaker: Gram.
sp.p: I, but, I can't ſtay to Heare you, now.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Choler, wil not you fight for your Maſter, valiantly?

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: No, I thanke you, Sir, your moyſture does allay my heat. Exit Choler.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Are you all gone? then, Apparent rari nantes in gurgite vaſto. I am King, I am King: by Tantalus I am as drie as an Horſe. He fals downe and ſleepes. Magus charmes him. O, ſome drinke, ſome drinke.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Alte dormi, Irioni, Chiriori, Eſſera, Chuder, Fere; Pax, Caspor, Prax, Melchior, Max, Balthaſar, Ymax, Adimax, Galbes, Galbat, Galdes, Galdat, Hax, pax, max, alte dormi. Poeta ſnores: Magus waues his rod ouer him, and runnes round about him. Oh, ho, ho, ho, ho, ho; O, ho, ho, ho, ho, ho. Dragons fly ſwiftly, Dragons fly ſwiftly.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Dancing about Poeta. O, ho, ho, ho, ho, ho. O, ho, ho, ho, ho, ho. O, ho, ho, ho, ho, ho.

l.stage: They goe leiſurely about him, ſaying this charme.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: O ho, ho, ho, ho, ho. O ho, ho, ho, ho. O ho, ho, Dauncing about him. ho, ho, ho, hoy—

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: O ho, ho, ho, ho, ho. O ho, ho, ho, ho, ho. In his ſleepe.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: What a Rogue's this? hee laughes at vs in his Dreame.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: O ho, ho, ho, ho, ho. O ho, ho, ho, ho, ho:In his ſleepe. Some drinke, Tantalus, ſome drinke, ſome drinke; or I will—

sp.speaker: Phyſ.
sp.p: What will he doe?

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: By the—by the—

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: He's about to ſweare ſure by ſomewhat.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: By the great—By the great—

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: He will ſweare by the Great.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: By the great—By the great—

sp.speaker: Phyſ.
sp.p: 'Tis ſo great 'twoun't come out.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: By the great Hogs-head at Heidelburge, Logicus is a Blockhead.

sp.speaker: Phyſ.
sp.p: Well ſaid i'faith, I perceiue there is ſome remembrance of ones friends in Wine.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: Corinna, will you kiſſe? will you kiſſe cockle-kiſſe? cloſe, cloſe, you Whore.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Oh, here's a braue Dreamer!

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: I will make this Verſe like a Nut-hooke-like a Nut-hooke-and then pull downe—pull downe the Moone with it. He begins to riſe.

sp.speaker: Phyſ.
sp.p: Sure, Magus, you han't charm'd him well.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Let me alone; I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: Come kiſſe, my Pigeon, come kiſſe, my pretty Corinna, Nibble a little, my Loue; nibble againe, and againe.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Hay day! he's at's Hexameter and Pentameter Verſes in our tongue: 'ſaith I thinke in ſome ſuch humour this kind of Verſes was firſt made amongſt vs.

p.hi: My purſe is richer thē th' Mines rich India brings forth.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: You ſhall not neede to make a ſhort Verſe to that Sir: weele be very ſhort with you. He is about to picke his pocket.

p.hi: Take off your whole one, or take a ſowſe o' the chops.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: Beſhrow his drunken fingers; Magus you ha' not charm'd him well.

p.hi:
Altè dormi, pax, prax, max; aliè dormi, Galbos, Galbat:
Galdes, Galdat: pax, prax, max, alte dormi.

sp.speaker: Phyſ.
sp.p: See what's in his pocket. Cheiromantes takes out a purſe and lookes in it.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: A murren on't, here's nothing but a Purſe with a paper in't.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Let's ſee it, why, whats here? Verſes!Hee takes the paper and reads it.
Tranſlated by mee vpon occaſion of Ethicus his inuiting mee to Supper.

q.l: The fruitfull Earth does drinke the raine;
Trees drinkes the fruitfull Earth againe.
The Sea does drinke the liquid Ayre;
By the Sunnes beames the Sea-waues are
Drunke vp; which is no ſooner done,
But ſtraight the Moone drinkes vp the Sunne.
Why then, companions, doe you thinke
I may not with like freedome drinke?

sp.p: This had beene loſt, if I had not giu'n the Rogue his Anacreon againe. Is this the rich Purſe? Come, 'ifaith wee'll e'en ſerue for a Voyder, and carrie him away, whiles hee is drunk, rid the roome of him.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Roome for a Poet, Roome for a Poet, Roome for a Poet. Exeunt Omnes, carrying away Poeta on their ſhoulders.
ANd haue you beene in Italie too?

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: In the moſt parts of the World, Sir.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: You haue diſpos'd your obſeruations by heads! haue you not?

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: They are yet Sir but a miſcellany, but I am now in reducing of them.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: And what may the ſumme of them be?

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: Sir, they are principally drawne from the People, and Country: diſcourſing vpon the policie, and naturall diſpoſition of the firſt; as on the ſituation, and fertilitie of the ſecond.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: Hum, the method is ſufficiently approoueable: but I like that very well that you place Policy firſt; and would wiſh you to proſecute that fully, with the moſt ſubtle examinations of your pureſt iudgement: 'twill be worth your trauaile: and 'tis a maine fault of your common Geographers, that now-a-dayes doe rather garniſh the margine of a Map, then materially deſcribe it; and onely draw a companie of lines through it; as if they had rid ouer the Countrie to take notice onely of the high-wayes; which yet a Carriers Horſe knowes better then they; neglecting in the meane time more ſolid obſeruations; whileſt their fancies (I will not ſay iudgements) are weakly ſatisfied with theſe fruitleſſe ſuperficialities; not vnlike your ſedentary Students, who for the attaining of a little glorie with ſome few leſſe iudicious of their owne Sect, ſtirred vp with a contemplatiue ambition, earneſtly proſecute thoſe ſtudies, which themſelues ſhall neuer reduce vnto practice, in the actions of their life.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: Sir, the obſeruation of gouernment was my firſt and principall intendment, eſpecially in ſome ſecrets of ſtate, as yet (to my knowledge) not obſeru'd, at leaſt not reueal'd by any.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: As what?

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: I will ſhew vnto you.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: But how could you come vnto the knowledge of them?

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: You ſhall vnderſtand that too. The ſecret is concerning the happie detection of ſuch, as from enemy-ſtates, are vſually ſent to the ſubuerſion of a Land; my meanes of attayning to the knowledge of this Myſterie, was my acquaintance with a Gentleman in Italie, who hauing beene one of the moſt practis'd Intelligencers in Europe, vpon the death of his Lord, who imploy'd him, fell into great wants; when, out of the fulneſſe of a grieued mind, and the rather to excite in me a compaſſion of his griefes, vnfolded vnto mee the whole ſecret.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: Proceed.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p:
The Italian Lord, that imploy'd this Gentleman, furniſhed him alwayes with money, that hee might caſt himſelfe
into what ſhape he would, then ſent him to the enemies Land, where liuing, (either concealing his owne Countrey, or profeſſing a diſlike of it) and inſinuating himſelfe into the acquaintance of men next to the beſt, would, commonly by entertaining their humours, and giuing occaſion of ſuch diſcourſe at any meeting, with much Art and eaſe, allure euery man, to diſcouer (euen for glory, to ſhow who could ſhow moſt) all intended and ſecret imployments into forraine Lands; by this meanes hee would learne the whole deſigne, agent, time, and whatſoeuer other neceſſarie circumſtance; then the perſon to be imploy'd, being commonly of eſtate not beyond himſelfe, hee would vpon ſome ſought (though but ſlight) occaſion, grow ſo farre acquainted with him, as to intreat the courteſie of Nations of him, to carry a Letter from him to that Countrey; which being with all courteſie granted, he would, againſt the time of his departure, prouide a Letter fairely written, containing nothing but ſome complement, or lighter buſineſſe to his friend —

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: Who? to his Lord?

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: No, Sir, but to another agent, whom his Lord imploy'd at home, as this Gentleman abroad.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: Proceed then.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: VVithall giuing his friend in charge, vpon their loue, to giue all courteous entertainment to the bearer thereof; as, to prouide him a fit lodging, with all other complements of friendſhip: then reading this Letter to the Gentleman, to free him from all ſuſpicion of falſe dealing, would ſeale it in his preſence, and deliuer it to him—

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: VVhat deuice was there-in this?

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: This Letter, Sir, being written by the Art of Steganography, contained the whole intendement of this imployd Meſſenger. That Art (as Trithemius has at large diſcouer'd, or rather taught it) proceeds vpon many deuices, as the putting together euery firſt letter of a word, or euery laſt, or euery ſecond, according to the compact before lay'd betweene theſe two friends. Vpon the receit of which, proceeded firſt a moſt courteous entertayning, and then vpon the maturitie of his intendements, an artificiall detection of al his deſignes.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: All this beares a iuſt probabilitie of truth. VVell, Geographus, we ſhall take a further notice of your wants and worth; and ſince you haue ingeniouſly diſcouer'd both your free education, preſent ſtate, and vnauoydable affection to Aſtronomia, and, as you ſay, hers mutually to you, I ſhall, I truſt, effectually, in your behalfe, remooue the vnwillingneſſe of her Mother Phyſica. But withall, I hold it a courſe, not altogether without Policy, to inquire of Aſtronomia, the diſlikes, for which ſhe does except againſt you, and therein by a praeuenient diſcretion, exactly to manifeſt a reformation; for this time the expectation of ſome buſineſſe admits not a further continuance of our diſcourſe.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: I ſhall reſt, Sir, at the bountie of your vertue.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p:
A Gentleman of parts worth the taking notice of; well, ſuch wits muſt bee nouriſht: 'tis the ſaying of my Tacitus: Ingenia, ſtudi
que oppreſſeris faciliùs quàm reuocaueris; & I remember he there ſhewes an analogie between mens wits and their bodies: They are (ſaith hee) both of them long a making, but ſoone marr'd. And indeed, young wittes that are worth the nouriſhing, when they ſee themſelues neglected, are too-too prone to fall to deſperate reſolutions, arguing thus with themſelues, That if Vertue and Learning cannot aduance them; by a reaſon from the contrary, neither Vice nor Ignorance can debaſe them; thus from bad premiſes drawing a worſe concluſion, they ouerthrow in a moment the workmanſhip of many yeeres. But my Kinſ-woman Hiſtoria ſayd ſhe would be here by this. Oh, here ſhe comes.
NOw Couſin, what? alwayes ſad? alwayes ſad?

sp.speaker: Hiſto.
sp.p: Doe you admire at my ſadneſſe, when you know, nay when you are the cauſe of it?

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: I? Couſin? how? how?

sp.speaker: Hiſto.
sp.p:
Your continuall declamations, Sir, againſt my moſt
lou'd Poeta, a man whoſe praiſes admit no Hyperbole; no, they tranſcend all; and whoſe worth we may admire rather then expreſſe.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: Why Couſin? my declamations ha' beene onely againſt his faults, not his perſon, and ſo farre —

sp.speaker: Hiſto.
sp.p: Nay, for your State-diſtinctions you may reſerue them to your ſelfe, you can loue and hate the ſame man at the ſame time by a diſtinction; I doe but plainely relate the truth vnto you, and I thinke there is hardly any man could more violently haue inueigh'd againſt him then your ſelfe; excepting old froward Ethicus; his age indeed muſt alwaies be correcting ſome body.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: VVhy, but why ſhould you regard him, when it ſeemes he little regards you?

sp.speaker: Histo.
sp.p: Marry, and little reaſon he hath, when he ſees the beſt of my friends, your ſelfe, and Ethicus to neglect him. But otherwiſe I'me ſure he did loue me once: there haue bin of the Hiſtorias that haue beene well belou'd by Poets, and thoſe the moſt renowned in all ages: as by admired Homer, the greateſt glory and Shame of Greece, the one for his worth, the other for his wants: then by diuine Maro, that beautifull wonder of Nature; and eſpecially by one Lucan, a worthy Gentleman of Rome, beſides many more; that if you would vouchſafe but to grace him, his Lawrel would be the crowne of your glory.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: I but he beares loue to Aſtronomia.

sp.speaker: Hiſt.
sp.p:
I vnderſtand ſo much: but I think that rather the exiliency of ſome paſſion, then any conſiſtency of a ſettled deſire. I haue indeede heard alſo of ſome of the Aſtronomias that haue beene belou'd by Poets; as by Manilius, Pontanus, and ſome other, who haue written whole Bookes in the praiſe of their beauties; but it ſeemes their beauties had ſuch ſmall diuinity in them, that they could not raiſe, to any height of poeticke rapture, the wits of their admirers. And there was alſo one Lucretius, a Romane Gentleman, in former times that fell in loue with Phyſica, ſhee from whom Phyſica the mother of Aſtronomia deriues now both her name and linage, which Gentleman, in the paſſion of his loue, writ books in the praiſe
of her beauty; but what wrinkle-fac'd Verſes they are, let the preſent age iudge; and if her beautie was like his lines, ſure ſhe was paſt her Three-ſcore, when hee fell in loue with her; but alas, there was neuer any of that family that euer came neere the Hiſtorias for beauty.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: VVell, Couſin, then what is the imployment wherewith you will taske me?

sp.speaker: Hiſt.
sp.p: VVhy, if you meane to haue mee aliue long, change your diſlike of Poeta into loue, and reforme him if you will, but not hate him; admoniſh him, intreat him, woo him, and in a word, winne him vnto mee; and thoſe hymnes of your praiſes, and relations of your glory ſhall bee put in the mouth of poſteritie; that ſooner ſhall the Common-wealth dye, then your fame.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: Well, Couſin, you haue now enough admoniſht me, entreated me, woo'd mee, and in a word wonne me: referre the finding out of meanes, and the accompliſhing of your deſire to the priuacie of my meditations.

sp.speaker: Hiſtor.
sp.p: Reuerend Polites, pardon the vnmannerlineſſe of my diſordered paſſions; loue reſiſted growes rude and furious: but I will not inſtruct your wiſedome; onely remember my life lies in your hands.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: And that ſhall not periſh if I can ſaue it. There are many accuſations in againſt this Poeta, and ſome of them I perceiue will be proſecuted; he has bad, and good parts; he has a wilde head, yet may be reform'd, and then there's a man ſau'd: a good purchaſe; nay, Hiſtoria is ſau'd, that's a double. Well, then ſince I muſt loue him, I will ſaue him: if hee proue good, I winne two; if bad, 'twill bee but the loſſe of one, of Hiſtoria; who already profeſſes, that, without him, ſhe ſhall be loſt.

div.head: ACTVS IIII. SCENA III.
ASTRONOMIA, ASTROLOGIA, ARITHMETICA, POETA, MEDICVS, MVSICA.

sp.p: OH, I'me ſo hot, I could drinke a whole Riuer of water.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p:
Nay, if you talke of drinking, I could drinke my
ſelfe halfe a doozen Helicons off at a draught: Muſica, fetch a flaggon of Wine.

sp.speaker: Aſtron.
sp.p: Nay, let it be pure Water.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Haue a care what you doe: 'tis as much as your life's worth.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: By Ioue wee will haue our liquor about vs. Goe Wench, why, Sir, ſhould not ſhe drinke?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Why, to drink in the heat of an Ague is preſent death; and I remember Galen in his Booke de conſuetudine, relates a Storie of Arius a Peripateticke, who dyed ſuddenly, being forc'd to drinke a full draught of colde water in the hea • of his Feuer; though according to the preſcriptions of his Phyſicians: yet, I confeſſe, in him there was another adioyn'd cauſe, which Galen in the ſame place makes mention of, to wit, his ſtomake being alwayes very colde, hee reſolu'd on a perpetuall abſtinence from all colde nouriſhments, ſo that this aduentitious colde of the water hee dranke, wrought not onely againſt his diſeaſe, but alſo againſt his conſtitution.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: Oh that was it, that was it; then fill out the liquor.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: You Poets would make mad Phyſicians; or at the beſt but deſperate Paracelſians; But Aſtronomia, you ſtirre too much; and ſo the heate of your diſeaſe increaſes to an inflammation: you muſt reſt more, you muſt reſt more.

sp.speaker: Aſtron.
sp.p: Nay, I ſhall neuer liue, if I leaue mouing.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: I, but not ſo faſt; you walke as faſt as you do when you are in health.

sp.speaker: Astrol.
sp.p: Indeed, mee thinkes, ſhee keepes alwayes the ſame pace.

sp.speaker: Arith.
sp.p: I, but if you marke it, 'tis not a direct Progreſſion, but a kind of giddie turning Round, which proceeds from a lightneſſe of the head, caus'd by her diſeaſe.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: I diſlike your dyet; for in the verie hotteſt of Summer, when the Sunne is in Cancer, you eate the hotteſt meate, feeding altogether vpon Crab; which two concurrent heates of the Meat and of the Weather, are able to caſt any man into the inflammation of a Feuer.

sp.speaker: Aſtron.
sp.p: Indeed, I confeſſe that; and 'tis at that ſeaſon, my only dyet.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: I, but 'tis bad; and againe 'tis very good to feed vpon varietie of meate.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: Say you ſo! marry, I thinke, you'l prooue a paradoxicall Paracelſian your ſelfe; if you hold ſuch Tenents: for you know, Sir, 'tis the moſt receiued opinion of Phyſicians, that varietie of meates diſturbes concoction.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Sir, I hold that opinion rather to argue the Authors ſuperſtition, then iudgement: for our nature delighteth in varietie, and thoſe meats which the ſtomake doth with pleaſure deſire, it doth moſt embracingly attract, and concoct moſt faithfully, beſides the ſubſtance of our bodies conſiſting of a various nature, as moyſture, ayre, and the like, one of theſe parts may be more ſpent then another, by labour, or other meanes; ſo that a man had need, for the vndoubted ſupply of all theſe parts, receiue a great varietie of nouriſhments, that there may be a reparation for whatſoeuer the bodie does euacuate.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: I vnderſtand Sir.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Beſides, Aſtronomia, going abroad you neuer take care in what Ayre you walke.

sp.speaker: Aſtron.
sp.p: Indeed, I confeſſe, I am too neglectiue of that.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Oh, that's a chiefe matter to bee prouided for; for the verie ſame ayre ſometimes is hurtfull for one part of the bodie, and good for another.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: How? is that poſſible?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Sir, 'tis a truth obſeru'd by Guido Cauliacenſis; and in particular of the ayre of Paris; where, if the ſame man haue a wound in his head, and another in his thigh; it hurts the one and heales the other.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: That's prettie i'faith: the reaſon, the reaſon, Maſter Phyſician.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p:
'Tis thus, Sir, the ayre there is cold and moyſt, and therefore moſt hurtfull for the head; and againe, the ſame ayre by an obſcuration of the ſpirits, a degrauation of the bloud, and a condenſation of the humours, whereby they are made leſſe quicke to flow downe, does therefore make the wounds of the thighes more curable, whiles the courſe of the humours is intercepted, whoſe defluence or flowing downe
would hinder the cure of the wound.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: You Phyſicians, I perceiue, ſometimes haue ſome of Apollo in you.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: Pray, Medicus, tell me one thing; you'r a Phyſician; I haue heard Geographus relate of a place in his Trauels, where the people are heal'd by Muſicke: is that poſſible?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: O yes: Ile confirme it by mine owne experience: I knew a young Gentle man that marri'd a young Gentlewoman; who being extraordinarily faire, and he as melancholy, grew into a great iealouſie, that ſhee had made him a Cuckold, vpon which conceit, at the firſt but light, the ſtrength of his melancholy and iealouſie working together; he fell into a ſtrong perſwaſion that he had Hornes: the beſt Phyſicians were ſent for, vs'd all medicines and inuentions to cure him, nothing preuail'd, whereupon they left him, intreating his wife to be patient, and expect his recouerie in time. Away they went, and none but a little boy was left in the roome to tend the Gentleman, when vpon a ſuddaine there comes mee by, a Bag-pipe-player, at the ſound of whoſe Pipe the Gentleman ſuddainely aroſe, leapes about the Chamber, beates his head againſt the wall, ſo long, till at laſt he had broke his face in diuers places that the bloud guſhed out; vpon the effuſion of which melancholy bloud, that had corrupted his braine and phantaſie, the Gentlemans Hornes were beaten off againſt the wall, and the Gentlewoman became as honeſt a woman after that time, as any in Europe.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: In good faith, you Phyſicians are the onely fellowes in the world to tell Tales by Gentlewomens Bed-ſides, whiles they are ſicke.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: I, this Cure was by the effuſion of bloud, but they whom Geographus tolde of, were healed without any ſuch meanes.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p:
Ile ſatisfie you in that by another particularitie of experience: I knew another Gentleman, who being very ſicke of a contagious diſeaſe, and finding no remedie by Medicine, the Phyſicians caus'd Muſicians to bee brought into the roome, and play; at the hearing of which Muſicke, hee ſuddainely leapes and continu'd dancing ſo long, till the laborious
exagitation of his whole bodie, had by ſweat and breathing diſſipated the contagion.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: I wonder you Phyſicians doe not turne Trauailors, you'd haue an aduantage beyond them all, by making good your Relations, by giuing a reaſon for them.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: O by no meanes, Sir; for if wee ſhould trauaile into forraine Lands, our skill would there faile vs; by reaſon of the difference of the Countrie, and our ignorance of their conſtitutions and dyet.

sp.speaker: Aſtron.
sp.p: Muſica, ſome drinke; mee thinkes, I haue not one iot of moyſture in me.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Muſica, fetch none, ſhee ſhall drinke no more.

sp.speaker: Aſtron.
sp.p: I muſt drinke, the World was not in ſuch a combuſtion at Phaeton's driuing the Chariot of the Sunne, as I am in now.

sp.speaker: Aſtrol.
sp.p: Come, come, Medicus, the ſtrictneſſe of your preſcriptions muſt be diſpenc'd with, a little.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Will you ſpoile her, Aſtrologia?

sp.speaker: Aſtrol.
sp.p: Ile warrant you, ſhee'l neuer dye of this diſeaſe, I haue calculated her Natiuitie, to know ſo much beyond your Art: the ſixt Houſe of her Horoſcope, wherein all her diſeaſes are Prefiguratiuely regiſtred, promiſes a better iſſue of her ſickneſſe then ſo: beſides, ſhee ſhall haue an happie Wombe, for I find in her Horoſcope, Ʋenus in her Exaltation, to wit, in Piſces, and Iupiter in the fift Houſe, the Radiation of Ʋenus falling on the Firſt Houſe, and of Iupiter on the Eleuenth, Luna being in the Seuenth, illuſtrating the Fift Houſe with a Sextile Radiation; ſhee ſhall haue a beautifull Daughter, her name ſhall be Optica: there ſhall appeare at her Birth foure Sunnes, and as many Rain-bowes, and the Ayre ouer-againſt theſe Rain-bowes, ſhall ſeeme to bee full of Looking-glaſſes, and in the middle of each Raine-bow ſhall appeare a Peacockes taile, which being reflected from the Looking-glaſſes, ſhall proiect an infinitie of colours in the Ayre.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Aſtronomia, you goe too much, you'l neuer leaue your Walking, and if Copernicus were aliue againe, 'ifaith hee'd make you ſtand ſtill.

sp.speaker: Aſtron.
sp.p: Some drinke. She drinkes and fals.

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: Helpe, Aſtronomia fals.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: Marie, Heauens forbid.

sp.speaker: Medic.
sp.p: I, here's your drinke.

sp.speaker: Arith.
sp.p: Ah, Aſtrologia, you made no Reckoning of this ſickneſſe, I ſhall ſcarce e're truſt you againe, as long as I know you: Come, let's haue her in, let's haue her in. Exeunt omnes.

NOw my ſweet Deuils, I am euen ſicke with expecting when Medicus will come and viſit me: I feare, his phyſicke cannot worke vpon Poeta: that rogues Verſes, I thinke, are a counter-charme againſt all our coniurations: a rope on his ſixe-footed lowſie Hexameters: ſure, the ſlaues skin is inchanted; the quilting of Aiax ſhield was but a thin Cheu'rill to it.

sp.speaker: Phyſiog.
sp.p: Why, but doe you thinke 'tis impenetrable?

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Oh, farre tougher then a Tanners: I haue heard of a Poet, that hauing beene buried a matter of two or three hundred yeeres, has beene taken vp againe whole, without the leaſt periſhing of his skinne, as faire as any Ʋellome.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: Nay, by this Hand, I hold them to be euerlaſting villaines.

sp.speaker: Phyſiog.
sp.p: And I know by his lookes, if he once ſettle his affection vpon a wench, hee'll purſue her more ſwiftly then euer Apollo did Daphne; for hee'll ouertake her before her Metamorphoſis.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: I, and I know the raſcall to haue a ſoft and moiſt Hand, by which I alſo infallibly know hee loues: for take a Poet without his wine & his wench; and if he make not drie, pitifull drie Verſes, Ile forſweare Fortune-telling as long as I liue.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: But, I hope, that wench ſhall not be Aſtronomia.

sp.speaker: Phyſiog.
sp.p: Ne'r feare that: I haue ſeriouſly obſeru'd (taking an oportunitie the other day to looke on her) the whole compoſure of her Face; and firſt for her beautie, I muſt confeſſe it abſolute; for there are the two cauſes of all beautie; a moſt exquiſite Symmetrie, or correſpondent commenſuration of the parts; and an exact mixture of colours, which addes vnto the proportion an incomprehenſible pulchritude: ſince which time, I haue taken a like view of Geographus and Geometres; now for their heights, Geographus is ſomewhat lower then ſhee; but Geometres is of her pitch iuſt; for the lines of proportion in their faces, I muſt confeſſe, I can hardly iudge which is moſt like her, well, I hope yet 'twill be Geometres, or if Geographus doe win her, 'twill be by his comely deportment: 'faith I wiſh him well, but wee muſt worke for them that feele vs in the fiſt.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Well, Rauens, croke here, and whoſoe'r comes by, make a prey of him; in the meane time Ile to Aſtrologia, for I know not what's the reaſon on't, but my Spirits cannot informe me of any thing ſhee does, ſo that I muſt of neceſſitie to Aſtrologia, to know how things proceed: but there's one Galilaus an exquiſite Mathematicean, an Italian: whom I came very lately acquainted with, by admirable lucke; and he has promis'd to helpe me to a glaſſe, by which I ſhall ſee all things as perfectly repreſented in Aſtronomia's houſe, as if I were there: till which time I muſt take the paines to haue it by relation; but to your charge, to your charge; croke Rauens, croke.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: HEre comes ſome body, Phyſiognomus; ſet a good Face on't and Affront him; and Ile ſet my Fingers a worke, preſently.

sp.speaker: Phyſiog.
sp.p: Hold thy Hands there, 'tis Sanguis, hee's of our ſide, ſtay a little.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p:
Well, I ſhrowdly ſuſpect my Maſter for this phyſicke:
but mum, I am o're-heard, I feare.

sp.speaker: Phyſiog.
sp.p: How now, Sanguis? why doeſt thou bluſh ſo?

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Doe I bluſh?

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: I'me ſure thou look'ſt as red as fire; I thinke all the Bloud in thy body is in thy face.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Well, well, all your words will not make me a jot redder then I am: but, if you talke of bluſhing, I thinke you haue more need to bluſh, if you knew the report that goes of you.

sp.speaker: Phyſiog.
sp.p: Of vs?

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: I, of you; but eſpecially of Cheiromantes.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: Of me? what?

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Nothing, but that you are a Cut-purſe.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: I defie mine accuſers, and I call honeſtie it ſelfe to witneſſe, that I get my liuing by my fingers ends.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Come, come, leaue theſe proteſtations: a bad cauſe is better defended by ſilence, then argument.

sp.speaker: Phyſiog.
sp.p: Faith 'tis true; let vs be friends: and ſince thy Maſter Medicus has taught thee to Kill, wee'll teach thee to Steale: but honeſtly, Sanguis, honeſtly.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: We three will ſet vpon the next man we meet.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: I would 'twere Choler that broke my head t'other day: o' that condition, I'd ſtay; but my Maſter has ſent me to Magus. I muſt begone.

sp.speaker: Phyſiog.
sp.p: Nay, ſtay a little longer now, Sanguis: who comes yonder? doe you know his Face?

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Well, you wo vvill helpe me?

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: My Hand ſhal be alwaies readie to help my friend.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Choler giues Sanguis a boxe on the eare, and they fall to cuffes. Choler, I'me Sanguis, and here's my head.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Sanguis, I'm Choler and here's my hand.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: How? three againſt one? Hercules himſelfe could not fight with ſuch diſaduantage: there's no ingenuitie in this; Ile take his part for pittie-ſake at auenture, be it right or wrong. He helps Choler

sp.speaker: Phyſiog.
sp.p: O my noſe, my noſe—

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Ile make you too Sanguis crie your Bloodie noſe before I ha' done.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: O my hand! my hand! O you rogue, you bow it quite double almoſt.
sp.stage: Enter MVSICA with a packe and a bottle of drinke.

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: Why men, beaſts, furies, what doe you meane?

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: Choler, Choler, draw thy knife, and flit Phyſiognomus his noſe.

sp.speaker: Phyſiog.
sp.p: Ah you dull rogue, doe you kicke?
sp.stage: Enter PHLEGMATICO with a pipe of Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: Oh, Phlegmatico! thou'rt welcome; but prethee throw away thy pipe; vnleſſe 'twere one could make them dance after it, and ſo coole their furie.

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: Why, ho!

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: Orpheus, they ſay, by muſike held beaſts by the eares; let Muſica then hold the beaſtly furies of you, that are now by the eares.

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: Why, ho!They leaue fighting.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: He has pickt my pocket. Sirrah, Cheiromantes, you rogue, where's my hand-kercher?

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: Nay, giue him his hand-kercher, I ſaw you take it: there, there is thy hand-kercher, Melancholico: why I thought thou hadſt beene no fighter.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: 'Faith, ingenuitie made me fight, when I ſaw three vpon one.

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: Come, come, for ſhame, be friends; you ſhall all be friends before you part.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: Nay, I'm angrie with no body: I did but fight, to make them leaue fighting.

sp.speaker: Phyſiog.
sp.p: Nor we; for the quarrell was not ours.

sp.speaker: Cheir.
sp.p: Nor we; for the quarrell was not ours.

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: I thought 'twas Choler, and Sanguis, they ſtill are prouoking one another: What haſt thou in thy bottle, Muſica? Nepenthe to reconcile the Gods?

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: 'Faith here's drinke to reconcile theſe furies, if they will?

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: Come, Muſica, doe you beginne, and wee'll all dance after thy pipe.

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p:
You haue ſpoke truer then you thinke, for there is a Piper comming after me, and ſomebody elſe; they'll be here
anon: well, here's to you all then. Shee drinks. Hee drinks.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: Phlegmatico, here's to thee.

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: Sanguis, here's to thee.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Choler, here's to thee.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Cheiromantes, haue at you.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: Worke. (Choler drinks) Phyſiognomus, will you taſte this liquor?

sp.speaker: Phyſiog.
sp.p: Play off: (Cheiromantes drinks) Well then, I am laſt, Ile drinke to you all; Ile leaue ne'r a jot: (Hee drinks) there, Muſica, there's thy bottle.

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: Sanguis and Choler ſhake hands; are you friends?

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: Cheiromantes, they ſay, you can tell fortunes; is it true?

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: Trie me.

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: Let's know all our fortunes then.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: Come on, let me ſee your hand, ſweet Muſica: you ſhall be belou'd of two, a Courtier and a Scholer; you ſhall loue the Courtier more; but the Scholer ſhall haue you; and it ſhall ſo come to paſſe, that the Courtier ſhall afterward be your ſeruant: your husband ſhall be exceeding melancholy: you ſhall haue three ſonnes; the firſt ſhall be call'd by his fathers name (but I know not what that ſhall be) and hee ſhall be extreme diſcontent and ſolitarie; and if he preuent a conſumption, he may liue till fortie; for longer he cannot, being of a cold and drie conſtitution: the ſecond ſhall be called Timido, and hee'll be indanger of being bit with a mad dogge; which if he ſcape, he may liue till fiftie: the third ſhall be called Iucundo; the other two tooke after their father; but hee'll take after his mother; hee will be exceedingly giuen to good cheere, muſike, and women: he will be in danger of a Surfet; and of Fire; and if he ſcape theſe two, eſpecially burning, he may liue to be an old man.

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: Tell me mine next.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: You, Phlegmatico; 'twill be long ere you can get you a wife; yet you'll haue one, and one daughter; the child will die very young, of the blacke Iaundice, and your wife of the dropſie.

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: Sirrah, I ſaw you ſteale before, and now I heare you lie, you rogue.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: Tell me mine next.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: Ile tell you yours in your eare. He whiſpers in Melancholico's eare.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: Thanks, deare Cheiromantes.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Nay, and fortunes be ſo good that are told in ones eare; Ile haue mine told in my care too.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: Thus 'tis then. He whiſpers in his eare.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Piſh, this is no ſuch fine fortune.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Tell me mine openly.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: Why, this 'tis: You, Choler, ſhall be ſomewhat happy in your wife: her name ſhall be Poenitentia; you ſhall haue two children; and one ſhall take only after you, his name ſhall be Furioſo. He ſhal die in his young age, in an Ale-houſe, of a ſtab in at the mouth, which ſhal paſſe thorow his tongue, and braines. The other child ſhall be a daughter; ſhee ſhall take after her mother; her name ſhall be Lacryma, a modeſt ſober girle, and one that ſhall be well beloued by wiſe men.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Well, this is a prettie mixt fortune; now, what's thine owne fortune and thy fellowes?

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: Oh, ſtarke naught, ſtarke naught; Ile conceale them.

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: Then fare you well; I can ſtay no longer.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: 'Faith you ſhan't goe yet; what haue you in your packe?

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: What's that to you?

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: Prethec, Muſica, tell mee, what thou haſt in thy packe?

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: Why, becauſe you ſpeake kindly now, and intreat me, Ile ſhew you.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: Hay, braue! what's here?

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Morrice-bels?

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: And waſte-coates, and napkins?

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Why, how cam'ſt thou by them?

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p:
Why, thus: my Miſtris had beene ill a good while, and becauſe I tended her very carefully; ſhee gaue mee leaue to recreate my ſelfe to day; and i'faith I light on merry companie, where they vs'd theſe jinglers: and when they had
done, they pray'd mee to carrie them home with this bottle of drinke.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Faith, and there were enow, wee'd dance.

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: Enow? now I thinke on't, there's iuſt enow, there's ſixe paire.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Faith wee'll to it then, but what wouldſt thou doe, Muſica?

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: Why, Ile play the maid Marian.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p:
A match, a match: dreſſe, dreſſe, wee'll haue braue jingling.
〈…〉 .

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: I can't dance.

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: Nay, prethee be not ſullen, good Melancholico.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: If I doe, Ile weare no bels.

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: Why then lay one paire aſide.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: But I woun't dance now.

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: Why, Melancholico?

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: I woun't dance, vnleſſe I haue one of the wrought waſte-coates.

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: Why, now they haue put them on.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: I care not, I woun't dance elſe.

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: Come prethee, Cheiromantes, ſlip off thine againe and change with him; Melancholico muſt haue his ſullen humours. So, now vve want nothing but the Tabor wee talk't of: but 'tis no matter, ſince he does not come, wee'll ſing, and ſo make muſike to our ſelues. Who can tune the Morrice beſt?
sp.stage: Enter an hobby horſe dancing the Morrice and a Tabourer.
sp.p: Oh, The hobby horſe ruſhes on them, and throwes them all downe. here they are both, here they are both.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: O my arme, my arme!

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: O my ſhinne!

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Ah, murren on him; who the deuill's this?

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: I haue hurt my breſt.

sp.speaker: Phyſiog.
sp.p: O the ſide of my face!

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: A rope on you, muſt you throw me quite downe?

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p:
Prethee dance the morrice quietly with vs: vp, vp, ho, and wee'll dance. They 〈…〉 , the 〈…〉 ouer 〈…〉 them all a ••• e, 〈◊〉
Muſic • , and runnes away with the Tabourer.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: A murren goe with you—Muſica, who play'd in the hobby-horſe?

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: No, I muſt not tell.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Come then, wee'l goe now to Barly-breake.

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: I but there's one odde: what ſhall he doe? ſit out euery time?

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: Yes faith, and giue a reaſon of the other three couples meeting.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Agreed: runne.

item.hi: Sanguis.
Muſica.
Phyſiognomus.
Cheiromantes.
Melancholico.
Phlegmatico.

sp.speaker: Choler.
